image.altText: An Ipswich Community Youth Service teacher and student look at a book together

items.synopsis: West of Brisbane, this 16-year-old was vandalising cars and spent time in a watch house. An innovative education program has him on a brighter path.

title.children: 'When I don't have stuff to do, I do stuff that's naughty': Young offenders find a better path

image.altText: A qantas plane taking off into a clear blue sky with a city skyline at the bottom in the distance

items.synopsis: August was meant to be the month where Qantas would prove it had done the impossible after the pandemic devastated the airline. Instead, it spent a week embroiled in controversies that won't be Alan Joyce's responsibility to clean up.

title.children: Qantas is no stranger to turbulence, but it's flown headfirst into controversies it didn't see coming

image.altText: A man looking at a destroyed vehicle near a road.

items.synopsis: Progress in Ukraine's counteroffensive has been slower than expected, but its forces are building momentum in the country's south, and could be just 15 kilometres away from a major prize.

title.children: Why Ukraine could be just 15km from forcing Putin to make an impossible choice

image.altText: Firefighter tries to douse bushfire at night at Stanthorpe.

items.synopsis: Firefighters say grass fires, not bushfires, are Queensland's greatest threat this week. Here's why being prepared for a catastrophic fire warning is essential.

title.children: Additional firefighting aircraft on stand-by as parts of Queensland face catastrophic fire risk

image.altText: The chair of ASIC, James Shipton, during a press conference.

items.synopsis: If this matter wasn't so serious, Treasury's responses to former ASIC chairman James Shipton's letters about his experience at the regulator would make rich material for an episode of the British political satire Yes Minister, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Former ASIC boss said his job led him to despair. What happened next was like an episode of Yes Minister

image.altText: A firefighter works at a site which was hit during Russia's drone attacks in Odesa.

items.synopsis: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy announces plan to dismiss the country's defence minister as Russian drones hit a port critical to Ukraine's grain exports, injuring at least two people.

title.children: Ukraine defence minister's dismissal announced as Russian drones strike critical Ukrainian port

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: Local shares make gains at open with company profits, inventories, and wages data due mid-morning. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX opens higher after US markets gain with rate pause optimism

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have opened up on Monday, with gains in local commodity stocks on higher prices. The benchmark index ASX 200 was up 51 points or 0.7 per cent to 7,330 at 10:15am AEST. Most sectors were higher, with energy (+1.5pc) and basic materials (+1.4pc) leading the gains. Liontown Resources (+10.3pc), Paladin Energy (+7.4pc) and Karoon Energy (+4pc) were among the top movers. On the way down, Lake Resources lost 4.7 per cent while Bendigo and Adelaide Bank shed 3.1 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: Australian shares have opened up on Monday, with gains in local commodity stocks on higher prices.
The benchmark index ASX 200 was up 51 points or 0.7 per cent to 7,330 at 10:15am AEST.
Most sectors were higher, with
energy (+1.5pc) and basic materials (+1.4pc) leading the gains
Liontown Resources (+10.3pc), Paladin Energy (+7.4pc) and Karoon Energy (+4pc) were among the top movers.
On the way down, Lake Resources lost 4.7 per cent while Bendigo and Adelaide Bank shed 3.1 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European stocks steadied, ending the session flat as a decline in luxury and auto shares was offset by gains in mining and healthcare. The STOXX 600 posted its biggest weekly gain since mid-July. The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 0.01 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe gained 0.1 per cent. Oil prices jumped on Friday, touching their highest level in over seven months, driven by expectations of tightening supply. Gold prices wavered throughout the session but were last slightly higher.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What about in Europe

children.content: European stocks steadied
, ending the session flat as a decline in luxury and auto shares was offset by gains in mining and healthcare.
The STOXX 600 posted its
biggest weekly gain since mid-July
The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 0.01 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe gained 0.1 per cent.
Oil prices jumped on Friday, touching their highest level in over seven months, driven by expectations of tightening supply.
Gold prices wavered throughout the session but were last slightly higher.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US stock indexes settled for a mixed close on Friday after a US jobs report showed an uptick in unemployment, cementing expectations that the Federal Reserve will let interest rates stand at its September meeting. The three major indexes gave up earlier advances, losing momentum as the session progressed and investors digested the data ahead of the long US holiday weekend. The S & P 500 and the Dow ended modestly green, while the tech-laden Nasdaq closed nearly unchanged. All three indexes notched gains on the week. "Today, people are coasting into the holiday weekend with relief that the job numbers were solid," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group in Omaha. "There are signs of the economy slowing, which is what the Fed wants to see," Detrick added. "It likely opens the door for no rate hike at the next Fed meeting in three weeks." The Labor Department's payrolls report showed the US economy added more jobs than expected last month, but the rising unemployment and participation rates, along with a welcome cool-down in average hourly wage growth, solidified expectations that the Fed will let key interest rates stand this month. Financial markets are pricing in a 93 per cent likelihood of such a pause this month, according to CME's FedWatch tool. But what the Fed will do beyond September remains an open question.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened on Wall Street

children.content: US stock indexes settled for a mixed close on Friday after a US jobs report showed an uptick in unemployment, cementing expectations that the Federal Reserve will let interest rates stand at its September meeting.
The three major indexes gave up earlier advances
, losing momentum as the session progressed and investors digested the data ahead of the long US holiday weekend.
The S
P 500 and the Dow ended modestly green, while the tech-laden Nasdaq closed nearly unchanged.
All three indexes notched gains on the week.
"Today, people are coasting into the holiday weekend with relief that the job numbers were solid," said Ryan Detrick, chief market strategist at Carson Group in Omaha.
"There are signs of the economy slowing, which is what the Fed wants to see," Detrick added. "It likely opens the door for no rate hike at the next Fed meeting in three weeks."
The Labor Department's payrolls report showed
the US economy added more jobs than expected last month
, but the rising unemployment and participation rates, along with a welcome cool-down in average hourly wage growth, solidified expectations that the Fed will let key interest rates stand this month.
Financial markets are pricing in
a 93 per cent likelihood
of such a pause this month, according to CME's FedWatch tool.
But what the Fed will do beyond September remains an open question.
